buildup.text: George Miller's 1956 paper 'The Magical Number Seven' showed that working memory has a strict capacity limit.

discovery.text: Chunking beats the limit: you can't remember 10 digits, but you can remember a phone number by grouping them into

twist.text: Modern research suggests the limit is closer to 4 items, not 7. Miller was generous ‚Äî our memory is even smaller.

climax.text: Working memory's tiny capacity explains why learning must be broken into small pieces. Overload kills understanding.

punchline.text: Your brain's scratch pad holds 4 things. That's it. Teach accordingly.
